person.note: On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1. The inscription mentions both Hades, see Introduction 6.10.2, and the Land of Onias (̓Ονίου γᾶ).
Jewishness may be suggested based on relative’s name (Shabtit [9]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness may be suggested based on father-in-law’s name (Shabtai [52]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
This seems to be the same name, with a male nominative suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1. Yet, from context it is clear that this person is female.
CPJ only included this ostracon because it was found with Jewish ostraca, in the “Jewish quarter” of Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
The ostracon is dated.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
The papyrus is dated.
See above, n. 5.
See above, n. 6.
See Introduction 2.1.
See above, n. 5.
See above, n. 6.
This seems to be the same name, with another, Greek accuative suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1.
In Greek – ὡς ἐτῶν εἰκοσιπέντε λόχους.
On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.
The inscription is dated.
This nominative suffix assumes another declension.
Jewishness may be suggested based on father’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
The ostracon is dated.
Appears in a land-register as the mother of an unnamed tenant, whose landowner is Jewish (Joshua [9]), but this family need not be, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
The papyrus is dated.

state.note: Seuthes (2), Ptollas (2) and Proto (2)’s mother, Theodorus (21)’s wife

person.note: This seems to be the same name, with another, Greek genitive suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
The papyrus is dated.
This seems to be the same name, with another, Greek accusative suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1.
In Greek – ὡς ιε’.
On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.
In Greek – ὡς ἐτῶν μ’.
See above, n. 7.
In Greek – ν’.
Her brother, buried in the same burial cave, is Isaac (60), see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
In Greek – κζ’.
Buried with persons with biblical names, see Introduction 6.5.5.

The ethnic identity of her husband is problematic. He bears a biblical name but could be Christian because he is late, see Introduction 6.6.7. However, he bears a pagan title, which is problematic for either, and see Introduction 6.6.5.
The papyri are dated.
Jewishness may be suggested based on relative’s name (Shabtit [9]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
This seems to be the same name, with another, Greek genitive suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness may be suggested based on relative’s name (Shabtit [9]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
The inscription was acquired in Gizeh. Provenance unknown.
Early editors thought he was Jewish because they believed the inscription originated from Leontopolis, but see Introduction 6.5.1, and there is no evidence for this.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
Her son described in the text as ̓Ιουδ (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.4.
This declension is probably a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.5.
Described in the text as ̔Εβρέα (Hebrew), see Introduction 6.1.2.

Some persons in this papyrus have Hebrew names, which suggested to the editor that “The whole nomenclature betrays persons of Jewish extraction,” but this is the Christian era, and they could be Christian. The Coptic subscription particularly suggests this, see Introduction 6.6.7.
The papyrus is dated.
Perhaps a relative of Joanna (3) who wrote this letter, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
The papyrus is dated.
See Introduction 2.1.
In Greek – ὡ ἐτῶ μθ’.
The inscription was acquired in Gizeh. Provenance unknown.
Early editors thought he was Jewish because they believed the inscription originated from Leontopolis, but see Introduction 6.5.1, and there is no evidence for this.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
In Greek – ὡς ἐτῶν κε’.
On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.

See Introduction 2.1. This name derives from the same root as the one indicated in the title. The suffix, however (if indeed correctly reconstructed) is completely different, and see Introduction 2.8.5.
Jewishness may be suggested based on husband’s great-grandfather’s name (Shabtai [55]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness may be suggested based on father-in-law’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
This name derives from the same root as the one indicated in the title. The suffix, however is completely different, and see Introduction 2.8.5.
Jewishness may be suggested based on husband’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
This name derives from the same root as the one indicated in the title. The suffix, however, is completely different, and see Introduction 2.8.5.
Jewishness may be suggested based on husband’s grandfather’s name (Shabtai [52]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.

state.note: Apeitheon (1) and Esther (2)’s daughter, Theodorus (27)’s sister

person.note: On the interchange of ι and ει see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.3.2.
Jewishness suggested based on mother’s name, but see 6.6.7, concerning dates. The papyrus is also not clear about the relationship between the two women.
This name derives from the same root as the one indicated in the title. The suffix, however is completely different, and see Introduction 2.8.5.
Jewishness may be suggested based on relative’s name (Shabtit [10]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
This name derives from the same root as the one indicated in the title. The suffix, however is completely different, and see Introduction 2.8.5.
In Greek – τῶν ἀπὸ τοῦ ὅρμου.
The woman who complains against her is Jewish because she files the complaint with the archons of the politeuma, see Introduction 6.4.2.1, but this need not be true for Tetoeus.
The papyrus is dated.
See previous note.

Jewishness suggested based on the fact that the letter is addressed to the (Jewish?) archons in Heracleopolis, see PC 29 (2001) p. 75, and see Introduction 6.4.2.1, but Polyctor, her son-in-law, is designated Μακεδόνος (Macedonean), and this suggests a different ethnic affiliation, and Sostrate is his wife and could herself be non-Jewish.
The papyrus is dated.
On the double consonant see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.3.4.

Jewishness was suggested based on the name Dosithea found in the inscription, (but see under Dosithea [G/F], n. 1), absence of decoration and similarity to Jewish epitaphs of Leontopolis (see Introduction 6.5.1), but none of these are decisive.
See Introduction 2.1, and above, n. 5.
Buried with persons with biblical names, see Introduction 6.5.5.
See above, n. 7.
Buried in the same tomb with Joshua (23), see Introduction 6.5.5.
See Introduction 2.6.1. The form is undeclined.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish.
See Introduction 2.6.1. The form is undeclined.
Both forms appear in the document.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
See above, n. 2. On ש transliterating s see vol. 1, Introduction 2.2.5, pp. 20-1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. However, this is a list of names, none of them strictly Jewish.
For this abbreviated version see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.1.
In Greek – δούλ.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
The ostracon is dated.
Jewishness suggested by her presence in an otherwise all-Jewish ostracon form the “Jewish quarter” of Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
See above, n. 2.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The papyrus is dated.
See above, n. 2.
Jewishness may be suggested based on husband’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
Jewishness may be suggested based on relative’s name (Shabtit [9]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.

div.note: The name ̓Αλίνη appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 19; Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 26.
The name ̓Αμμωνοῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 26.
Preisigke, Namenbuch, 474, mentions the name Χενενοῦβις and refers the reader to the name Σανανοῦπις.
Egyptian name (Δωσάριον), appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 94.
The name ̔Εριεῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 103.
The name Μαροῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 207.
The name Φιλοῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 464. It is obviously derived from the Greek name Φίλων, see Introduction 1.5.1.
The name Πτολέμα appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 348. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Ptolemaius, see Introduction 1.5.1.
The name Πτολλοῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 350. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Ptolemaius, see Introduction 1.5.1.

The name Σαραποῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 364. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Σαραπίων, see Introduction 1.5.1, and derives from the Egyptian god Serapis, see Introduction 1.2.3.
Names with the prefix Σεμθ are recorded on papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 369.
The name Σενῦφις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 377.
An Egyptian female name with the prefix Ταβικ is recorded in Preisigke, Namenbuch, 404, but it is not this one. This one may be a scribal error or an error in reading.
The name Ταῆσις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 405.
This name and many others with the element Ταυα are often found in Egyptian papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 412-3.
The name Ταψωῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 424.
The name Τασεῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 418.
The name Ταθάϊς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 406.
The name Ταυ῁ρις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 422.
The name Τκοῦϊς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 440.
The name Τετεῦς is recorded often on papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 431.
The name Θαλοῦς / Ταλοῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 127, 408.
The name Θαμῆνις / Θαμῖνις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 127.
The name Θασεῖς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 129.
The name Θερμοῦθις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 136.
